repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem
---
If a highlighter query returns a significant number of predicate non-matches, the highlighter will scan well past the end of the window.

Solution
---
In the iterator returned from `iter_captures`, accept an optional parameter `until_line`. If no parameter provided, the behavior is unchanged, hence this is a non-invasive tweak.

Fixes: #25113 nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter#5057

comment_data.body: `end_line` is more consistent. Also need to tweak the type on line 711.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -717,15 +717,16 @@ function Query:iter_captures(node, source, start, stop)
   start, stop = value_or_node_range(start, stop, node)
 
   local raw_iter = node:_rawquery(self.query, true, start, stop)
-  local function iter()
+  local function iter(until_line)

comment_data.body:
This should use the `get_range()` from below. I know `metadata` will be `nil`.

I might be better to refactor by removing the break so the logic isn't duplicated.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,9 +241,15 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line, is_spell_nav)
     end
 
     while line >= state.next_row do
-      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter()
+      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter(line)
 
       if capture == nil then
+        if node then
+          local start_row = node:range()

comment_data.body: Right, I forgot about Lua's amazing tolerance for nulls
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,9 +241,15 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line, is_spell_nav)
     end
 
     while line >= state.next_row do
-      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter()
+      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter(line)
 
       if capture == nil then
+        if node then
+          local start_row = node:range()

comment_data.body:
Index with `nil` error.

I think this whole block needs to be surrounded with `if capture`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,15 +241,15 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line, is_spell_nav)
     end
 
     while line >= state.next_row do
-      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter()
+      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter(line)
+      metadata = metadata or {}
 
-      if capture == nil then
-        break
+      local range = { root_end_row + 1, 0, root_end_row + 1, 0 }
+      if node then
+        range = vim.treesitter.get_range(node, buf, metadata[capture])
       end
-
-      local range = vim.treesitter.get_range(node, buf, metadata[capture])
       local start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col = Range.unpack4(range)
-      local hl = highlighter_query.hl_cache[capture]
+      local hl = capture and highlighter_query.hl_cache[capture]
 
       local capture_name = highlighter_query:query().captures[capture]

@@ -241,15 +241,15 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line, is_spell_nav)
     end
 
     while line >= state.next_row do
-      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter()
+      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter(line)
+      metadata = metadata or {}
 
-      if capture == nil then
-        break
+      local range = { root_end_row + 1, 0, root_end_row + 1, 0 }
+      if node then
+        range = vim.treesitter.get_range(node, buf, metadata[capture])
       end
-
-      local range = vim.treesitter.get_range(node, buf, metadata[capture])
       local start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col = Range.unpack4(range)
-      local hl = highlighter_query.hl_cache[capture]
+      local hl = capture and highlighter_query.hl_cache[capture]
 
       local capture_name = highlighter_query:query().captures[capture]

comment_data.body: Do we need to adjust `next_row` if there is no node?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,40 +241,43 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line, is_spell_nav)
     end
 
     while line >= state.next_row do
-      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter()
+      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter(line)
 
-      if capture == nil then
-        break
+      local range = { root_end_row + 1, 0, root_end_row + 1, 0 }
+      if node then

comment_data.body:
I put the fast-forward (`root_end_row + 1`) there just b/c it's in the spirit of the while loop to invariantly end with `next_row > line` / for `next_row` to reflect the state of the iteration

It probably doesn't make a huge runtime difference though since even if you start over every subsequent `line`:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/091b57d766a48768ca97240a0ec8f63d2c1aaac0/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua#L238-L241

you will get an empty list every time since you're starting from `line`.

So yeah, just aesthetics.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,40 +241,43 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line, is_spell_nav)
     end
 
     while line >= state.next_row do
-      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter()
+      local capture, node, metadata = state.iter(line)
 
-      if capture == nil then
-        break
+      local range = { root_end_row + 1, 0, root_end_row + 1, 0 }
+      if node then

comment_regular_data.body:
Commit should be `perf(treesitter)` (release note tooling expects that).

Backport?

> We'll also want to extend this to column too at some point.

Might be better then to already implement this as a `position` tuple (or `Range`) now, even if the `col` isn't used yet?

> > We'll also want to extend this to column too at some point.
> 
> Might be better then to already implement this as a `position` tuple (or `Range`) now, even if the `col` isn't used yet?

Most functions already accept `row` and `col` as separate positional args so I wouldn't begin deviating in _this_ PR.
The highlighter stuff is very line-based from my cursory look (also, 80 characters superiority :P). Can let the column idea marinate though.

> The highlighter stuff is very line-based from my cursory look (also, 80 characters superiority :P). Can let the column idea marinate though.

There's an open PR to add columns limits #18109 (using `synmaxcol`) and #15405 (adding column info to the decor provider). The issue is that it's too hard to properly account for conceal and wrapping.

Initial impression after the perf change: I don't really notice any improvements regarding nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter#5057, sometimes I feel it's even a downgrade

One thing that I feel certain about is the initial parsing time goes up, making opening a file that causes the lag to be worse than before
Oops. I think this breaks iterator usage with `for` : https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter-context/blob/master/lua/treesitter-context/render.lua#L140-L142

Not too related but it may also break nvim-treesitter CI 
https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/blob/34829e9221b18af0c6e2066dc27e5e41901c2f62/tests/query/highlights_spec.lua#L60

> One thing that I feel certain about is the initial parsing time goes up, making opening a file that causes the lag to be worse than before

This change shouldn't affect parsing at all. Are you sure this isn't because you are running a debug build or something?
Im running a release build, probably because this now fights with nvim-treesitter `indent`, maybe?

I think this might be ok since `iter_captures` only returns a single value, however it means we can't add any more arguments to `iter()`.

Not sure what issues nvim-treesitter is having.
Actually, it won't break nvim-treesitter since we do `parser:parse(true)` for testing so there shouldn't be any issue related to parsing
This has little to nothing to do with parsing. The changes here are with the highlighter and the `highlights.scm` query.

> Oops. I think this breaks iterator usage with `for` : https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter-context/blob/master/lua/treesitter-context/render.lua#L140-L142

Oh no, did I push a bug?

My assumption was that `for` loops would pass in `nil` and so not see any difference in behavior:

```
Lua 5.4.6  Copyright (C) 1994-2023 Lua.org, PUC-Rio
> function upTo(limit) 
>>   local current = 0
>>   return function(foo)
>>     print(foo)
>>     current = current + 1
>>     if current <= limit then
>>       return current
>>     end
>>   end
>> end
> for number in upTo(5) do print(number) end
nil
1
nil
2
nil
3
nil
4
nil
5
nil
> 
```

> Not too related but it may also break nvim-treesitter CI
> https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/blob/34829e9221b18af0c6e2066dc27e5e41901c2f62/tests/query/highlights_spec.lua#L60

I guess I'll try this and find out
Don't test Lua 5.4, that's a different language
I think this change gets away with it but it means we can't add any additional arguments to the iterator.

> Don't test Lua 5.4, that's a different language

Thanks for the tip; is there a better REPL for Neovim's flavor of Lua than `:`?
I've raised https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25193, though not sure if there's a better way.
Lua 5.1 (or LuaJIT).

> Initial impression after the perf change: I don't really notice any improvements regarding [nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter#5057](https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/issues/5057), sometimes I feel it's even a downgrade
> 
> One thing that I feel certain about is the initial parsing time goes up, making opening a file that causes the lag to be worse than before

That's odd, I'm able to consistently bisect an improvement in `runtime/lua/vim/lsp/protocol.lua` to this change (i.e. built back and forth a few times just to make sure I didn't have anything weird cached). Before this commit it would take over a second per C-f/C-b. After, it's instant. I can also make random edits, sprinkle FIXME/TODO/etc, spam uncomment/re-comment the block, everything is instant. I tested both `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug` and `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release`

> Im running a release build, probably because this now fights with nvim-treesitter indent, maybe?

It should be fine, as the only global (i.e. outside of updating TSHighlighter internal state) side effect `on_line_impl` has is to set extmarks; is `nvim-treesitter` indent checking the highlight extmarks in the middle of a redraw and expecting them to be fully formed? But even prior to this commit they wouldn't be fully formed
@lucario387 maybe try `git checkout master && git pull origin master && make clean && rm -rf build` and run it from `VIMRUNTIME=./runtime ./build/bin/nvim --luamod-dev` (no install)?
(lucario knows, but you need to specify `$VIMRUNTIME` as well if you run straight from the build dir)

Ah, I see where it's a bit un-snappy, it's when you C-b back

But I still don't see a regression. After the commit, it's instant when C-f to end to the file, and slightly un-snappy going back up with C-b. But before the commit it's basically unusable the whole way.

Wait, C-b isn't slow at all. It's because I was in `tmux` 😂 . So yeah, I can't reproduce @lucario387 . I turned on

```lua
          pcall(vim.treesitter.start)
          vim.wo.foldexpr = 'v:lua.vim.treesitter.foldexpr()'
          vim.bo.indentexpr = "v:lua.require'nvim-treesitter'.indentexpr()"
```

as well as a ton of plugins, no dice.

> One thing that I feel certain about is the initial parsing time goes up, making opening a file that causes the lag to be worse than before

No difference here either; `vim runtime/lua/vim/lsp/protocol.lua +"InspectTree"` takes about quarter to half a second to show the tree regardless of which commit I build on

It's really a stark difference; initially I thought it wouldn't be a large factor speedup if it's just scanning one page vs a few pages, but I think the difference may actually be quadratic; because we weren't updating `next_line` on `capture == nil` before, we would start over on every line
It just feel the same in snappyness before and after the changes to me, probably because the file im testing on can't even be handled by Helix :D (more than 500ms parse)

Oh so you are not testing on `$VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/lsp/protocol.lua`? That one works fine for me.

For something that can't be handled by Helix, yeah that might beyond the scope of this (what about tree-sitter CLI?)

If you [profile with plenary](https://github.com/nvim-lua/plenary.nvim#plenaryprofile) and it doesn't come up with `on_line_impl` as the bottleneck then this won't help

Helix and ts CLI can handle it, that's for sure. Just that helix shorted and cancel the parsing whenever it takes more than 500ms for that action.

For `protocol.lua`, I did test it as well, just that it doesn't feel as snappy as when I open it on Helix, so I have yet to properly profile the changes

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: perf(treesitter): do not scan past given line for predicate match
